title: 112_s2111
content:
The Act titled "Cyber Crime Protection Security Act" amends Section 1961(1) of title 18, United States Code, to include penalties for fraud and related activity in connection with computers. Section 1030(c) of title 18, United States Code is amended to include penalties for cyber crimes, with fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both for certain offenses. Offenses for commercial advantage or financial gain may result in fines, imprisonment up to 10 years, or both. The penalties for cyber crimes under Section 1030(c) of title 18, United States Code include fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both for various offenses such as committing offenses in violation of laws, obtaining valuable information exceeding $5,000, and other specified actions. The penalties for cyber crimes under Section 1030(c) of title 18, United States Code include fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both for offenses causing loss, modification of medical care, physical injury, threat to public health or safety, or damage to a computer. The penalties for cyber crimes under Section 1030(c) of title 18, United States Code include fines, imprisonment up to 10 years, or both for offenses causing harm to government entities, national defense, national security, or affecting 10 or more protected computers in a year. Additionally, attempting to cause death from such offenses can result in imprisonment for any term of years or for life. The penalties for cyber crimes under Section 1030(c) of title 18, United States Code include fines, imprisonment up to 10 years, or both for various offenses. This includes fines, imprisonment for not more than 1 year, or both for certain offenses, fines or imprisonment for not more than 10 years for other offenses, and fines or imprisonment for not more than 10 years for specific offenses. SEC. 4. TRAFFICKING IN PASSWORDS.

Amends Section 1030(a) of title 18, United States Code by defining trafficking in passwords and means of unauthorized access to protected computers.

SEC. 5. CONSPIRACY AND ATTEMPTED COMPUTER FRAUD OFFENSES.

Amends Section 1030(b) of title 18, United States Code to specify punishment for completed computer fraud offenses. SEC. 6. CRIMINAL AND CIVIL FORFEITURE FOR FRAUD AND RELATED ACTIVITY IN CONNECTION WITH COMPUTERS. Section 1030 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include criminal forfeiture for individuals convicted of violating the section, requiring them to forfeit any property used in the commission of the violation or derived from it to the United States. The criminal forfeiture of property under this subsection, including any seizure and disposition of the property, shall be governed by the provisions of section 413 of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970. Civil forfeiture includes any property used to commit or facilitate violations of this section. The forfeiture of property for violations of this section is governed by specific laws, with duties performed by designated individuals. The Secretary of Homeland Security or the Attorney General may designate other persons for specific purposes. SEC. 7. DAMAGE TO CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE COMPUTERS. Amends Chapter 47 of title 18, United States Code by inserting section 1030A for aggravated damage to a critical infrastructure computer. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like 'computer' and 'damage'. A 'critical infrastructure computer' is defined as a system vital to national defense, security, economic security, public health, or safety, including gas/oil systems, water supply, telecommunications, power delivery, finance/banking, emergency services, and transportation. It is illegal to intentionally damage a critical infrastructure computer during a felony violation of section 1030, resulting in substantial impairment of its operation or associated infrastructure. The penalty for this offense is a fine, imprisonment for 3 to 20 years, or both. Probation is not an option for offenders. The law prohibits probation for individuals convicted of damaging critical infrastructure computers under section 1030. Imprisonment terms for this offense cannot run concurrently with other terms and cannot be reduced to account for separate violations. The law prohibits probation for individuals convicted of damaging critical infrastructure computers under section 1030. Imprisonment terms for this offense cannot run concurrently with other terms and cannot be reduced to account for separate violations. A term of imprisonment imposed for a violation may only run concurrently with another term for an additional violation of this section, subject to guidelines from the United States Sentencing Commission. SEC. 8 amends Section 1030(e)(6) of title 18, United States Code, to clarify that unauthorized access does not include violations of contractual agreements with Internet service providers or employers.
